channel.title: Andrew Denta
channel.description: Hi! I am Andrew Denta. I make balloons and websites. Feel free to check out my various projects!

item.title: Exodus Easter Egg Hunt
item.description: Great time with Exodus Church this morning at 3rd street park here in Bloomington! Not too many pictures, because it was oepn to the public, and they didn’t want me taking pictures of anyone who did not go to the Church.

item.title: Chicago Restoration Ministries
item.description: We made a bunch of balloons at the Restoration Ministries in Harvey, IL!

item.title: Pui Tak Balloons
item.description: We made a bunch of balloons at the Pui Tak Center!

item.title: Feedback
item.description:
Overview

I often find myself behind a sound board. I have always enjoyed contributing to any sort of performance through operating sound and lighting equipment. One problem I found myself facing time and time again was that of communication. I would wind up needing to do fifty things at the same time, and would constantly be riddled with requests.

“Can you turn me up in the monitors?”

“Hey Andrew, can you hear me back there? I don’t think my mic is working.”

“We have this video we need you to play tonight. It’s on this DVD at the 42 minute mark. We just need thirty seconds from that point.”

With many things trying to happen in a short period of time, I thought software might be a way to make my life easier. I spent an evening constructing a very basic MVP, to see if it might work for aggregating feedback from band members as to how well they can hear themselves.

How It Works

My goal with Feedback was to make it so people in a band can communicate to a sound technician what to change about their dynamics as easily as possible. I used two views, one for the people making requests about wanting to be turned up or down, and another to display this information. I did not focus too much on security for this application, as there was no sensitive information being communicated. Band members select ‘who they are’, and then drag a slider where they want it to be. We can than see all these changes here. On the admin view, once all requests have been satisfied, you can press the thumbs up emoji button, to let everyone know that you processed their request. This will reset their sliders to the middle position.

Results

We tried it out a few times, and it was hard to get people to use the site to log requests as to what they needed. For the time being, it seems the status quo will be here to stay, until I can figure out what the bottleneck is in terms of allowing everyone to tell me what they need done in an orderly fashion.

item.title: Add.ninja
item.description: I wanted to do something about people wanting to support charity, but falling short on contributing. I figured a good solution to this problem would be a website that hosts sponsored content, and gives the proceeds to charity. This way, people would still be able to support charity passively.

item.title: 4 letter words.
item.description: Summer 2015, I started getting passionate about how I could use advertising to change the world. After trying to build an alarm clock that woke people up with video ad’s, I decided to make a mobile trivia game. I took an archive of Jeopardy Questions and filtered out all answers that were not four letters long. Ads only appear if you run out of points. Points are gained by typing in the answers correctly. Points are used to buy hints, which give you one of the letters needed for the correct answer.
